Vaccine Administration

A.

Vaccine Administration

1.

Vaccine Selection and Dosing

* Select the appropriate flu vaccine formulation for the patient based on age and medical history (e.g., high-dose or adjuvanted for seniors, the regular dose for adults, and pediatric doses for children).

Choose the Injection Site

* Determine the appropriate injection site based on the individual patient's anatomy and health status.
+ Typically, the deltoid muscle in the upper arm (midpoint between the shoulder and elbow).
* Typically, the deltoid muscle in the upper arm is used.
+ Typically, injections are given in the deltoid muscle area of the arm for adults.
* The most common site for flu vaccine administration is the deltoid muscle in the upper arm.
* Typically, the deltoid muscle in the upper arm is used for adults and adolescents.
+ Typically, the deltoid muscle of the non-dominant arm for adults.
+ Typically, administer flu vaccines in the deltoid muscle area of the upper arm (approximately 1-2 inches below the acromion process).
* Typically, the deltoid muscle in the upper arm is used for adults.
+ The deltoid muscle in the upper arm (about 2-3 inches below the shoulder joint) is the recommended site for adults and children aged ≥1 year.
* Typically, the flu vaccine is administered in the deltoid muscle of the upper arm (preferably the non-dominant arm).
* Typically use upper arm or deltoid region for most adults.

* Commonly used injection sites include:
	+ Deltoid muscle in the upper arm (intramuscular administration).

* Typically, the preferred injection sites for flu vaccines are:
	+ Deltoid muscle in the upper arm (most common)
	+ Anterioralateral aspect of the thigh ( alternative )

III.
* Typically, the deltoid muscle in the upper arm is the preferred site, in adults.

* The recommended injection sites for adult include the deltoid muscle of the arm or the anterolateral aspect of the thigh.

* The preferred injection site is typically the deltoid muscle in adults (top outer arm)
* Alternate injection sites may include the quadriceps or vastus lateralis in children or individuals with deltoid limitations.

* Typically, the deltoid muscle in the upper arm is recommended due to its proximity to underlying structures, vasculature reduces potential for complication and is more visible and accessible than gluteal muscles.
* Typically, flu vaccines are administered in the deltoid muscle of the arm (in patients above infancy).
* Typically, the deltoid muscle in the upper arm (specifically the middle-third of the arm) is chosen as the optimal site for an adult.
+ Common sites: Deltoid region of the arm (typically recommended), or the mid-anterior thigh muscle in some circumstances.
* The preferred site for administering flu vaccines in adults is the deltoid muscle region located on the outer aspect of the upper arm.

* The preferred injection sites are:
	+ Deltoid muscle of the arm (recommended for adults)
	+ Anterolateral aspect of the thigh (for infants and toddlers)

III.

III.Administering the Vaccine 

1.Select an appropriate-sized needle:
	+ Standard needle size: 25-30G; 16-40 mm length (0.6 - 0.8 in)
2.Draw up the required dose of flu vaccine into the syringe (typically 0.5 mL per dose):
	+ Use aseptic technique when handling and preparing the vaccine to prevent contamination.

3.Inject the vaccine at a 90-degree angle into the muscle tissue using a quick, gentle thrust:
	+ Place pressure on the area after withdrawal of the needle.

3.Inject the vaccine into the prepared injection site at a 45-degree angle:
	+ Administer the vaccine rapidly and gently, using a single,straightforward motion.
+ Place pressure over the injection site for a few seconds to help reduce bleeding/minimize bruising.
+ Ensure the needle tip is completely covered by skin folds to minimize localized reactions.
+ Aim to insert the needle 0.5-1 cm (1⁄4 inch) below the skin surface.
+ Avoid multiple injections at different angles as it may cause tissue necrosis.
+ Hold the syringe firmly during injection to minimize discomfort and ensure proper delivery.
+ Withdraw the needle quickly to reduce discomfort.
+ Avoid inserting air into the muscle while injecting vaccine.
* After injecting the entire contents, quickly withdraw the needle from the site while keeping it at the original angle.
+ Avoid injecting vaccine into the subcutaneous tissue or fat layer, as this could be less effective.
+ Take caution not to inject the vaccine intravascularly (into a blood vessel).
+ Insert the needle tip only one eighth inch deep before depressing the plunger.
+ Keep the needle in place for about one second before withdrawing it at the same angle.
+ Insert the needle just beneath the skin to avoid any unnecessary discomfort, especially for sensitive patients.
+ Release the injection device slowly after the vaccine has been delivered.
+ Maintain gentle pressure while withdrawingthe needle tominimize bleeding or local reactions.
+ Remove the needle quickly while applying gentle pressure to the injection site.
+ Keep the patient still during administration.
+ Release the injection slowly; apply gentle pressure for 30 seconds if slight bleeding occurs.
+ Ensure the entire dose is injected completely and properly.
+ Ensure the vaccine is administered correctly and without excessive pressure.
+ Keep injecting until all contents of the syringeare emptied and administered correctly.

+ Maintain steady gentle pressure on the plunger until the full dose has been delivered

IV.Post-Vaccination Procedures 

1.Dispose of biohazardous waste properly, including the syringe, needle, and any packaging materials:
	+ Adhere to OSHA Bloodborne Pathogen Standard (29 CFR 1910.1030)
2.Document vaccine administration in the patient's medical record:
	+ Capture date, vaccine type, dose administered, and other relevant details.
+ Do not aspirate as this practice is not recommended due to it yielding low blood return with little clinical utility.
+ Take extra precautions when injecting smaller patients(e. g.youngerchildrenorfants).
+ Aspirate before injecting the vaccine by pulling back slightly on theplunger to ensure no blood return.
+ Inject the full dose (avoid partial administration).
